curam.util.common

Class JDEException

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Throwable
      • java.lang.Exception
        • curam.util.common.JDEException
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    JDEExceptionType, java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ClientException, DataAccessException, MessageException, PlugInException

    public abstract class JDEException
extends java.lang.Exception
implements JDEExceptionType, java.io.Serializable

    An abstract exception class that manages message localization. The purpose is to prevent the creation of exceptions other than those with an externalized message identifier.

    The JDEException chains exceptions using the "cause" property inherited from java.lang.Throwable. Chained exceptions will be reported correctly when needed. As the "cause" property was added in Java 1.4, this class is not compatible with Java 1.3 or earlier.

    The class is intended to be integrated with the system that generates error messages and their constant identifiers from the DocBook XML sources that describe them. To support this, each sub-class should implement the JDEExceptionType.getMessageLocalizer() method to return the message localizer that can localize messages. Typically, a CatalogMessageLocalizer will be used; it can look up the message ID in a message catalog (a properties file) and return the localized message string. The default implementation of the method JDEExceptionType.getMessageBuilder() returns a message builder object that can substitute simple strings for message placeholders using the "s" formatting type code (e.g., "%1s"). This can be overridden if more complex message builders are required.

    For example, where the error message strings are generated into curam.custom.CustomMessages.properties and the corresponding error message constants for the message identifiers are generated into curam.custom.CustomMessages.java, a new exception class curam.custom.CustomException would be written like this (extra constructors can be implemented as needed): 

     import curam.util.common.JDEException;
 
 public class CustomException extends JDEException
                              implements CustomMessages {
   private static final MESSAGE_LOCALIZER
       = new CatalogMessageLocalizer("curam.custom.CustomMessages");
 
   public CustomException(int messageID) {
     super(messageID);
   }
 
   public String getMessageLocalizer() {
     return MESSAGE_LOCALIZER;
   }
 }

    The CatalogMessageLocalizer is stateless and thread-safe, so it can be maintained as a static field of the class to avoid the need to instantiate copies every time it is used.

    To report a message with the identifier ERR_BAD_THING_HAPPENED, the typical usage of this class then becomes something like this: 

     throw new CustomException(CustomException.ERR_BAD_THING_HAPPENED);

    All localization of the message will occur automatically. If message arguments are required, the appropriate constructors should be implemented to support them (they just need to invoke the corresponding constructor in the super-class) and the arguments will be automatically applied to the message when the exception is reported.

    JDE exceptions and their derivatives can be linked together (independently of their causal exception) to allow several exceptions to be thrown as one if there are several problems found at one time (for example, the validation of the values of all of the fields on a page).

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • getMessage

        public java.lang.String getMessage(java.util.Locale locale)
        Gets a message string appropriate for a specific locale (not just the system default locale, which is no good for a server-side application). The message will be localized and built by applying the defined message localizer and message builder to the message object.
        Specified by:
        getMessage in interface JDEExceptionType
        Parameters:
        locale - The locale to use to translate the message.
        Returns:
        The localized message text for this exception.
        See Also:
        JDEExceptionType.getMessage(Locale)

      • getLocalizedMessage

        public java.lang.String getLocalizedMessage()
        Gets the message localized to the system default locale. This overrides the method to use JDEException.getMessage(Locale) passing the system default locale.
        Overrides:
        getLocalizedMessage in class java.lang.Throwable
        Returns:
        The localized message string.

      • getMessage

        public java.lang.String getMessage()
        Overridden to use JDEException.getLocalizedMessage(). The detail message of the java.lang.Throwable class is now inaccessible. This method does not add the messages in the chain of causal exceptions. For most purposes, the use of JDEException.toString() or JDEException.toString(Locale) is more appropriate.
        Overrides:
        getMessage in class java.lang.Throwable
        Returns:
        The localized message string.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Converts the exception to a string representation in the system default locale. This works the same way as JDEException.toString(Locale).
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Throwable
        Returns:
        The string representation of the chain of exceptions localized to the system default locale.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString(java.util.Locale locale)
        Returns a string representation of the exception including the string representations of all the causal exceptions. The exceptions are prefixed with the exception class name and separated by new-line characters.
        Specified by:
        toString in interface JDEExceptionType
        Parameters:
        locale - The locale to used when localizing the messages.
        Returns:
        The string representation of the chain of exceptions.
        See Also:
        JDEExceptionType.toString(Locale)

      • getMessageObject

        public Message getMessageObject()
        Gets the message object maintained by this exception. The JDE-style exceptions all store a message object independently from the inherited exception message string. This object is more suitable for localization and argument substitution than the simple string available from the Java classes.
        Specified by:
        getMessageObject in interface JDEExceptionType
        Returns:
        The message object managed by this exception.
        See Also:
        JDEExceptionType.getMessageObject()

      • addException

        public JDEException addException(JDEException e)
        Adds an exception to the linked list of exceptions. The newly added exception is returned to allow it to be added to a subsequent exception, and so on. This exception becomes the "next" exception of the newly added exception, so the returned exception is always at the head of the list. If the new exception is null, no action is taken and this exception remains the head exception and is returned.
        Parameters:
        e - The exception to add to the linked list of exceptions.
        Returns:
        The newly added exception (the next exception can be added to that exception). If the new exception is null, then this exception is returned instead.

      • getNextException

        public JDEException getNextException()
        Gets the next exception in the linked list of exceptions.
        Returns:
        The next exception, or null if this is the last exception in the list.

      • setNextException

        protected void setNextException(JDEException nextException)
        Sets the next exception in the linked list of exceptions.
        Parameters:
        nextException - The nextException to set.
